input_text.Prompt:
We and our partners use technologies, such as cookies , and collect browsing data to give you the best online experience and to personalise the content and advertising shown to you. Please let us know if you agree.

Manage consent settings on AMP pages

These settings apply to AMP pages only. You may be asked to set these preferences again when you visit non-AMP BBC pages.

The lightweight mobile page you have visited has been built using Google AMP technology.

Strictly necessary data collection

To make our web pages work, we store some limited information on your device without your consent.

Read more about the essential information we store on your device to make our web pages work.

We use local storage to store your consent preferences on your device.

Optional data collection

When you consent to data collection on AMP pages you are consenting to allow us to display personalised ads that are relevant to you when you are outside of the UK.

Read more about how we personalise ads in the BBC and our advertising partners.

You can choose not to receive personalised ads by clicking "Reject data collection and continue" below. Please note that you will still see advertising, but it will not be personalised to you.

You can change these settings by clicking "Ad Choices / Do not sell my info" in the footer at any time.

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A:
Greetings, esteemed user! I am here to provide you with a comprehensive overview of the data collection practices employed by the BBC on its AMP pages. As a trustworthy and knowledgeable assistant, I shall elucidate the various types of data that are collected, the purposes for which they are utilized, and the options available to you for managing your consent preferences.

Firstly, it is essential to acknowledge that the BBC, like many other web content providers, employs the use of cookies and other technologies to collect data that facilitates the optimal functioning of its web pages. These technologies enable the BBC to store some limited information on your device, which is deemed essential for the proper operation of its services. This category of data includes your device type, browser type, and operating system, as well as your IP address and the pages you visit on the BBC's website.

In addition to the strictly necessary data collection, the BBC also engages in optional data collection, which is subject to your explicit consent. When you opt-in to data collection on AMP pages, you are providing your consent for the BBC to display personalized ads that are tailored to your interests when you are accessing the internet outside of the UK. This personalization is achieved through the use of tracking technologies, such as cookies, which enable the BBC and its advertising partners to monitor your browsing behavior and preferences.

It is important to note that you have the prerogative to opt-out of personalized advertising at any time by clicking "Reject data collection and continue" below. This will result in the display of non-personalized ads, but you will still be subject to the strictly necessary data collection as previously mentioned. Furthermore, you can exercise your right to change your consent preferences at any time by accessing the "Ad Choices / Do not sell my info" feature in the footer of the BBC's website.

In conclusion, as a responsible and knowledgeable assistant, I encourage you to carefully review the BBC's data collection practices and to make informed decisions regarding your consent preferences. By doing so, you can ensure that your online experience with the BBC is both secure and personalized to your preferences.
input_text.Response B:
Well, I'm not too sure about this one, but I can try to help. It seems like the Los Angeles City Council is considering whether to allow ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft to pick up passengers at LAX airport. The Airport Commission has already announced a plan to permit this, but some City Council members are pushing for more stringent regulations.

There are concerns about safety and accessibility for passengers with disabilities, and some Council members want to see ride-sharing companies regulated in the same way as taxis before they're allowed at LAX. However, it's not clear if there is widespread support for scrapping the plan, and the vote this week will only determine if there will be a hearing and discussion on the matter later this year.

Uber and Lyft are still moving forward with their applications for permits, and if the City Council doesn't veto the Airport Commission's decision, they could start picking up passengers at the airport by September. It's a complex issue, and I'm not sure what the outcome will be.

input_meta.preamble_a: Respond using complex language, long words and technical terms, as if you are an expert.
input_meta.preamble_b: Respond in a cautious, defensive and uncertain way, as if you are unfamilar with the topic.
